msDesc.physDesc: This letter is two pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry (Monroe)” are written in pencil at the top, along with the date. The second page has “January 3, 1917” written where the “January 1” date is. It also has, typed, H.M. Page 2 in the top left corner.

div.p: Your letter is, I admit, a disappointment to me. When I send you my really best things, you are apt to refuse them. Then somebody else gets them, and that is too bad. However, I see your point about the length of the poem, although I see no reason why my work should not appear, any more than anyone else’s, in a single number; and I do think your theory of introducing new poets can be carried too far. It is just as important to help along those poets who are already on the road to permanent success as to introduce new ones. I think the thing should go hand in hand. However, as I have said before, it is your magazine.

I am enclosing a set of poems called "Lacquer Prints", because they are in the Hokku manner, and of which I think very highly. This is another side of my work from "Sea-Blue and Blood-Red, but I really think quite as important. The one I have scratched out I think has already appeared in "The Egoist". I have sent none of the others anywhere. I shall be awfully glad if you will take them and print them in a series, just as they are. They are in the order I should like. If there are too many for you, you can leave out some, but, of course, I should prefer to have you print them all.

I have not had any poems in "Poetry" since August, and, naturally, I wish to appear again. As I said before, if you could let me have them in the March number, when I shall be in Chicago, it would be very nice. Also, these will probably
be my contribution to the Imagist Anthology, which will appear in April, so they must be out before. There should be a note attached to the first one, saying that this poem was first translated into English from the German by Mr. Arthur Davison Ficke. The others are all original, with the exception of one other, an adaptation from Hokusai .

I am awfully glad you have taken Fletcher's article, and I know it will be a pleasure to him. Of course, you understand that you will have to pay him, at your usual rate, for it, as that was the understanding on which he sent it to me. I think you had better send the money to him direct.

Frost tells me that he refused to speak for you for your honorarium of ten dollars. That is too bad, both on your account and on his, but, of course, he needs the money. May I suggest that, of course, ten dollars is very little; and I confess when I agreed to do it, I thought that you would take “Sea-Blue and Blood-Red, and that would make a difference to me. However, these will do just as well, if you will take them.
